results.title: Harry Belafonte, Folk Hero
results.abstract: Cool and charismatic, Belafonte channeled his stardom into activism. He was a true people person, who knew how to reach, teach and challenge us.

multimedia.caption: “The bleaker my acting prospects looked,” Harry Belafonte wrote in his memoir from 2011, “the more I threw myself into political organizing.”
“The bleaker my acting prospects looked,” Harry Belafonte wrote in his memoir from 2011, “the more I threw myself into political organizing.”
“The bleaker my acting prospects looked,” Harry Belafonte wrote in his memoir from 2011, “the more I threw myself into political organizing.”

results.title: ‘Fatal Attraction’ Review: Here’s Why She Did It
results.abstract: A somber, psychology-heavy series tries to take the “erotic thriller” out of the erotic thriller.

multimedia.caption: Lizzy Caplan and Joshua Jackson in “Fatal Attraction,” which at times seems to be atoning for the 1987 film.
Lizzy Caplan and Joshua Jackson in “Fatal Attraction,” which at times seems to be atoning for the 1987 film.
Lizzy Caplan and Joshua Jackson in “Fatal Attraction,” which at times seems to be atoning for the 1987 film.

results.title: Spielberg, Who Regrets Cutting ‘E.T.’ Guns, Says Don’t Revise Old Works
results.abstract: “No film should be revised based on the lenses we now are either voluntarily or being forced to peer through,” Steven Spielberg said.

multimedia.caption: The director Steven Spielberg digitally removed law enforcement officers’ guns in “E.T.” for its 20th anniversary release, replacing them with walkie-talkies.
The director Steven Spielberg digitally removed law enforcement officers’ guns in “E.T.” for its 20th anniversary release, replacing them with walkie-talkies.
The director Steven Spielberg digitally removed law enforcement officers’ guns in “E.T.” for its 20th anniversary release, replacing them with walkie-talkies.

results.title: Work, Love, Dignity and Play: 10 Key Harry Belafonte Songs
results.abstract: He began his career during the 1950s folk revival and continued to record — and helped orchestrate “We Are the World” — while pursing his many other artistic and political interests.

multimedia.caption: Harry Belafonte had his commercial peak and his most prolific recording years in the late 1950s and early 1960s, but wove music throughout his remarkable career.
Harry Belafonte had his commercial peak and his most prolific recording years in the late 1950s and early 1960s, but wove music throughout his remarkable career.
Harry Belafonte had his commercial peak and his most prolific recording years in the late 1950s and early 1960s, but wove music throughout his remarkable career.

results.title: Karl Berger, 88, Who Opened Minds of Generations of Musicians, Is Dead
results.abstract: A vibraphonist, pianist, educator and musical thinker, he co-founded the Creative Music Studio to bring musicians together to foster improvisation.

multimedia.caption: Karl Berger in 1976 at his Creative Music Studio, near Woodstock, N.Y. He believed that everyone had musical talent and sought to teach players and listeners to concentrate their attention “fully in the moment.”

Karl Berger in 1976 at his Creative Music Studio, near Woodstock, N.Y. He believed that everyone had musical talent and sought to teach players and listeners to concentrate their attention “fully in the moment.”

Karl Berger in 1976 at his Creative Music Studio, near Woodstock, N.Y. He believed that everyone had musical talent and sought to teach players and listeners to concentrate their attention “fully in the moment.”

results.title: A Harlem Institution Reimagines How Americans Interact With the African Continent
results.abstract: After years of shifts, The Africa Center has the plans and space to grow. Can it raise the funds to carry out its ambitions?

multimedia.caption: Uzodinma Iweala, chief executive officer of The Africa Center, has helped move the institution beyond museum to a landing place for the African diaspora, focusing on its ideas and impact. The artwork in a hair-braid pattern by Nontsikelelo Mutiti was part of a recent exhibition.
multimedia.copyright: Elias Williams for The New York Times

results.title: Alec Baldwin Returns to ‘Rust,’ With Fake Guns and Rubber Bullets
results.abstract: An emotional gathering in Montana to finish a film that halted production in 2021 when its cinematographer was killed by a gun Mr. Baldwin was rehearsing with.

results.title: Ed Sheeran, Accused of Copying Marvin Gaye, Testifies He Wrote His Song
results.abstract: The singer was accused of copying his ballad “Thinking Out Loud” from Gaye’s “Let’s Get It On.” In court, he said he and a co-writer created the song, inspired by his grandparents.

multimedia.caption: Ed Sheeran arriving Tuesday at federal court in Manhattan. “Yes, Amy Wadge and I wrote the song ‘Thinking Out Loud,’” he testified.
Ed Sheeran arriving Tuesday at federal court in Manhattan. “Yes, Amy Wadge and I wrote the song ‘Thinking Out Loud,’” he testified.

results.abstract: The 38-year-old artist born Jason DeFord has been turning his struggles into music for years. Now it has a bit more twang, and a lot more attention.

results.title: Seth Meyers Speculates About Why Fox Dumped Tucker Carlson
results.abstract: Meyers joked that “firing Tucker for racism now after tolerating it for so long would be like canceling ‘Sesame Street’ because you just found out they were puppets.”
des_facet: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Late Late Show with James Corden (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)

multimedia.caption: “Fox couldn’t have cared less when Tucker was saying vulgar, offensive stuff on television about other people, but when he said it in private about Fox News executives, they were suddenly outraged,” Seth Meyers said.

results.title: April Stevens Dies at 93; Her ‘Deep Purple’ Became a Surprise Hit
results.abstract: Her unusual version of the standard, which she recorded with her brother, Nino Tempo, reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart in 1963 and won a Grammy.

multimedia.caption: The musical duo of April Stevens and Nino Tempo in the 1960s. The siblings stumbled on a spoken-and-sung lyrical device for a jazz standard during a rehearsal.

results.abstract: The director and star of the Volksbühne’s new show, based on a play by Lord Byron, picked up another role when one of the lead actors was missing in action.

results.title: Colorful Stories for Children, With the Darkest History as Backdrop
results.abstract: Whimsical children’s books signed El Pintor were a success in the Netherlands during World War II. Behind the pseudonym was a Jewish couple who used the proceeds to help the resistance.

results.title: At These Exhibitions, Death Is a Lively Subject
results.abstract: Museums are showing art from across the centuries that tackles core questions, through religious and secular lenses, about what happens when we die.

multimedia.caption: “A Woman Divided Into Two, Representing Life and Death,” 1790-1820, is part of the exhibition “Death Is Not the End,” on view through Jan. 14 at the Rubin Museum of Art in Manhattan.

results.title: Soviet Pop Art Duo Reunites for First U.S. Retrospective Since Their Breakup
results.abstract: The rebellious artists Vitaly Komar and Alexander Melamid founded their own artistic movement. They agreed to their first interview together in 20 years.

multimedia.caption: “Komar and Melamid: A Lesson in History” at Rutgers University’s Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick, N.J. The museum created the exhibit to highlight the duo’s collaborative work.

results.title: At This Museum Sixth Graders Learn Lessons in Democracy

results.title: ‘Ask Me What I’m Painting’: The Changing Role of the Artist in Residence
results.abstract: Art institutions are moving away from residency programs that support artists in seclusion, and toward those that engage with their communities.

multimedia.caption: Aliza Nisenbaum has been the artist in residence at the Queens Museum for two years. A show of her work, “Queens, Lindo y Querido” (Beautiful and Beloved), runs through Sept. 10.

results.title: Bears, Binoculars and Bucket-List Birds: A 15-Day Tour in Ecuador
results.abstract: A customized itinerary allowed a group of birders to observe hundreds of species across a range of elevations, all while staying at comfortable eco-lodges.
results.byline: By Dorothy Spears and Alexis Rockman

multimedia.caption: Birds spotted at the various lodges, including hoatzin (bottom left) harpy eagle (front and low-center), paradise tanager (above eagle), chestnut-fronted macaw, (flying off to the right), and gray-breasted mountain toucan (flying off to the left).

results.title: Russian Lawyers Ask Court to Ease Crackdown on Speaking Out
results.abstract: With thousands arrested for criticizing the invasion of Ukraine, the Kremlin has “criminalized dissent,” said a lawyer who asked the court to step in.

results.title: Harry Belafonte: A Life in Photos
results.abstract: He captivated audiences with his singing, achieved movie stardom and spent decades fighting for civil rights. In all his endeavors he broke racial barriers.

multimedia.caption: Mr. Belafonte at a recording session in the 1940s. Early in his career, he enjoyed some success but little creative satisfaction as a jazz-oriented pop singer before turning to folk music for inspiration.

results.title: Michael Denneny, 80, Dies; Editor Created Outlets for Gay Literature
results.abstract: In a largely closeted era, he was a founder of a magazine devoted to gay and lesbian writing and an imprint devoted to L.G.B.T. fiction and nonfiction.

multimedia.caption: Michael Denneny was the rare openly gay editor in a publishing industry in which many gay and lesbian editors were still closeted.
Michael Denneny was the rare openly gay editor in a publishing industry in which many gay and lesbian editors were still closeted.
